head.title: Moment of Decision: The Vote on China Trade

hedline.hl1: Moment of Decision: The Vote on China Trade

abstract.p: Michael N Bazigos letter disputes Alan Tonelson's May 18 Op-Ed article on arguments for and against China's entry into World Trade Organization (S)

block.p: Alan Tonelson (''China's Mythic Market,'' Op-Ed, May 18) is right to decry the portrayals of trade partners and business objectives in the Chinese trade debate as inaccurate. But it doesn't necessarily follow that ''trade agreements cannot bring widespread benefits to the United States.'' Framing the debate too narrowly around Chinese consumers obscures the real sources of value creation in today's economy.

Alan Tonelson (''China's Mythic Market,'' Op-Ed, May 18) is right to decry the portrayals of trade partners and business objectives in the Chinese trade debate as inaccurate. But it doesn't necessarily follow that ''trade agreements cannot bring widespread benefits to the United States.'' Framing the debate too narrowly around Chinese consumers obscures the real sources of value creation in today's economy.

Most of the future global opportunity is in e-business, and business-to-business transactions are assumed to account for 95 percent of that revenue, estimated at nearly $7 trillion annually by 2004. Competitive companies create this value by uniting customers and suppliers with their brand. Countries like China can help supply these companies with manufacturing, freeing the brand owner to focus capital on invention, innovation and customer satisfaction. The consumer element is but a small fraction of the whole.
MICHAEL N. BAZIGOS New York, May 19, 2000
The writer is worldwide director of globalization strategic consulting at PricewaterhouseCoopers.
